awd_titl_txt: CIF: Medium: Data Science: Analytics for Unstructured and Distributed Data
awd_abstract_narration:
CIF: Medium: Data Science: Analytics for Unstructured and Distributed Data
José M F Moura and Soummya Kar

Abstract

There has been a perfect storm of convergent technologies leading to an onslaught of data in digital format, ready to be acquired, stored, accessed, transmitted, and processed. This research develops quantitative analytics that are appropriate for data arising in many novel areas like social networks or urban environments, outside traditional engineering or science. This data is unstructured?it is no longer a single time series or a single image and cannot be naturally arranged in a vector or table. The data is distributed?it originates from many different agents, possibly scattered over a large physical space (e.g., a metro area). 

To process unstructured and distributed Big Data, the research extends traditional signal processing methods to distributed signal processing on graphs (DSPG) by associating two graphs with the data: 1) the ?physical graph? whose nodes index the data and whose physical edges capture the relations or dependencies among the data; and 2) the ?cyber? graph, possibly different from the physical graph, whose nodes index distributed processing units and whose cyber edges represent (local) communication channels among these units. To extend DSPG analytics to process distributed Big Data analytics, the investigators address the following challenges: 1) discover the structure of the underlying physical graph; and 2) design consensus+innovations scalable distributed algorithms to accurately process the distributed Big Data. Examples of important analytics include: forward filtering that computes y = Hx, where H is a graph filter or graph transform and x is the data associated with the agents; and inverse problems that compute solutions to linear systems Hx = y, where H and y are given, while x is reconstructed.

por.por_cntn:
Data is increasingly arising in new contexts, beyond the traditional time signals (like speech, audio, communications, or radar signals), or images, or video. Of interest, are applications occurring in the corporate or business worlds, social networks, biology, marketing, and many others. These data are not only big (Big Data) but also unstructured; this means the data does not neatly fit in a relational database or a table or a matrix. To structure these data, we assume that the data are supported or indexed by a graph and refer to the data as graph-based data. This is a novel field known in the literature by Graph Signal Processing (GSP) that we helped initiate (publication, January 2013). Beyond graph-based, the data is also distributed either because many there are many distinct and separate sources of data (like in health care several hospitals associated with the same health provider, or a bank with many business units or branches) and for many reasons (including privacy) one may not want to share the local data with a central location. The project was focused on developing principled processing methods for graph-based data and distributed data.

Intellectual merit: The project developed novel algorithms that addressed basic tools for processing graph data, including spectral analysis of graph-based signals, as well as distributed inference and distributed optimization associated with graph signal processing. We designed methods to 1) recover the structure of the graph from the available data; 2) design optimal graph filters as well as their fast decentralized implementations; 3) reconstruct distributed graph signals and perform inverse computations; and 4) learn from graph-based data by extending neural network architectures to include graph-based convolution. The methods developed accounted for random effects like noise that corrupt data, as well as communications noise among the cooperating data sources and processing units, or intermittent channel communications failures. We applied the graph signal processing methods developed to learning, in particular, convolutional neural networks (CNN), developing a novel learning architecture, topology adapted graph convolutional network (TAGCN), to process graph-based data. Through experimentation with synthetic data and real-world datasets, we have shown that TAGCN performs either similarly or better than other alternative geometric deep learning alternatives, usually with better computational properties.

Broad Impact: The project had broad impact. It extended in significant ways the state-of-the-art in processing unstructured data and distributed data. By combining graph signal processing concepts and methods with deep learning architectures, the project introduced a new deep learning architecture that is very well suited to process graph data. Beyond the discipline, on the education front, there were six PhD students that pursued their theses in the research supported by this grant (one of them a female PhD student) and four undergraduate students (two female undergraduate students) that pursued research in the context of this project. A new workshop on Graph Signal Processing was co-initiated with other interested researchers, now in its 4th edition, with over 100 participants.
